title: Final Cycle Population Values — PM_final
text: popPoints (NPAG ) Data frame final cycle joint population density grid points column names equal name random parameter plus prob associated probability point popMean final cycle mean random parameter distribution popSD final cycle standard deviation random parameter distribution popCV final cycle coefficient variation (SD/Mean) random parameter distribution popVar final cycle variance random parameter distribution popCov final cycle random parameter covariance matrix popCor final cycle random parameter correlation matrix popMed final cycle median values random parameter, .e. unknown mean unknown variance, fitted run postPoints (NPAG ) Data frame posterior population points first 100 subject, columns id, point, parameters probability.  first column subject, second column population point number, followed values parameters point probability. postMean nsub x npar data frame containing means posterior distributions parameter. postSD nsub x npar data frame containing SDs posterior distributions parameter. postVar nsub x npar data frame containing variances posterior distributions parameter. postCov NPAG : list length nsub, element npar x npar data frame contains posterior parameter value covariances subject. postCor NPAG : list length nsub, element npar x npar data frame contains posterior parameter value correlations subject. postMed nsub x npar data frame containing medians posterior distributions parameter.* shrinkage data frame shrinkage parameter. total population variance parameter comprised variance(EBE) plus average variance(EBD), subject's EBE Empirical Bayes Estimate mean posterior value parameter. EBD Empirical Bayes Distribution, full Bayesian posterior parameter value distribution subject. typical definition \(\eta\) shrinkage \([1 - \frac{SD(\eta)}{\omega}]\) \([1 - \frac{var(\eta)}{\omega^2}]\), \(\eta\) EBE \(\omega^2\) population variance \(\eta\). parametric modeling approaches \(\eta\) interindividual variability around typical (mean) value parameter population, usually referred \(\theta\). nonparametric approaches, assumption normality, \(\eta\) simply becomes subject's mean parameter value estimate. Pmetrics derives calculates shrinkage given parameter. $$popVar = var(EBE) + mean(var(EBD))$$ $$1 = \frac{var(EBE)}{popVar} + \frac{mean(var(EBD)}{popVar}$$ $$1 - \frac{var(EBE)}{popVar} = \frac{mean(var(EBD))}{popVar}$$ $$shrinkage = \frac{mean(var(EBD))}{popVar}$$ Shrinkage therefore fraction 0 1. text: poppar several choices population parameters. PM_result loaded PM_load, case $final field used, e.g. run1 <- PM_load(1) poppar = run1. PM_final object, typically field PM_result, e.g., poppar = run1$final. list containing three items order, name: vector weights, vector mean parameter values, covariance matrix. one distribution specified weights vector length 1 contain 1. multiple distributions sampled, weights vector length equal number distributions values sum 1, e.g. c(0.25,0.05,0.7).  means matrix may vector single distribution, matrix length(weights) rows number columns equal number parameters. model One three choices: PM_model object Character vector filename Pmetrics model working directory. model missing, two possibilities: **  poppar PM_result valid $model field, model poppar used. ** absence poppar valid model field, look file called "model.txt" working directory. data One three choices: PM_data object Character vector filename Pmetrics data working directory. data missing, two possibilities: **  poppar PM_result valid $data field, data poppar used. ** absence poppar valid data field, look file called "data.csv" working directory. either choice, value outputs can coded number(s) -99. number(s) replaced simulator output simulated values. nsamp number MM-optimal sample times compute; default 1, can number.  Values >4 take exponentially longer time. weight List whose names indicate type weighting, values indicate relative weight. Values sum 1. Names can following: none default. MMopt times chosen maximally discriminate responses times. AUC MMopt times chosen maximally discriminate AUC, regardless shape response profile. max MMopt times chosen maximally discriminate maximum, regardless shape response profile. min MMopt times chosen maximally discriminate minimum, regardless shape response profile. combination AUC, max, min can chosen.  "none" specified, weight types ignored relative value set 1. example,list(auc = 0.5,max = 0.5) list(auc = 0.2, min = 0.8). default list(none = 1). predInt interval fractional hours simulated predicted outputs times specified template data. default 0.5, means simulated outputs every 30 minutes time 0 maximal time template file.  may also specify predInt vector 3 values, e.g. c(1,4,1), similar R command seq, first value start time, second stop time, third step value.  Outputs times specified template file also simulated. simulate outputs output times template data (.e. EVID=0 events), use predInt = 0. Note maximum number predictions total 594, interval must sufficiently large accommodate given number output equations total time simulate .  predInt set cap exceeded, predictions truncated. mmInt Specify time intervals MMopt times can selected. include simulated times specified predInt. algorithm Optimal sampling algorithm. Currently modifiable option "mm". outeq Output equation optimize ... parameters pass PM_sim$new(). necessary, usePost = TRUE can used calculate individual MMopt times. case, number posterior distributions contained poppar$final$postPoints needs match number subjects data. can also pass include exclude limit subjects used data. work whether usePost TRUE FALSE. Note following arguments PM_sim$new modified. nsim zero outname "MMsim" combine TRUE clean Boolean parameter specify whether temporary files made course simulation run deleted. Defaults TRUE. primarily used debugging.

title: Create Probability of Target Attainment (PTA) object — PM_pta
text: simdata Can one multiple inputs shown examples using. simEx PM_sim simEx$data PM_simlist simEx$data[[1]] PM_sim_data NPex$post PM_post NPex$post$data PM_post_data NPex$data PM_data NPex$data$standard_data PM_data_data "simout.txt" matches files wildcard ability, see PM_sim simlabels Optional character vector labels simulation.  Default c('Regimen 1', 'Regimen 2',...). target One several options. vector pharmacodynamic targets, Minimum Inhibitory Concentrations (MICs), e.g. c(0.25, 0.5, 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, 32). single numerical value concentration, e.g. 10. sampled distribution using  makePTAtarget. list multiple targets combining multiple target_types used. , first target can vector, subsequent targets must single values avoid factorial expansion combinations. example, first target vector MICs corresponding target_type "time", second target value 10 corresponding target_type "min", third target value 50 corresponding target_type "max" example: target = list(c(0.25, 0.5, 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, 32), 10, 50). first value can also sampled distribution made makePTAtarget. target_type vector type target.  , place minus sign front make success less target ratio, e.g. target_type = c("min", "-min"). Available types: "time" percent time target within time range specified start end. Use "-time" percent time target. "auc" ratio area curve within time range target "peak" "max", ratio peak max (synonymous) concentration target within time range. Use "-max" "-peak" make success less target ratio. "min", ratio minimum concentration target within time range. Use "-min" make success less target ratio. single numeric value, must correspond observation time common PMsim objects simdata, rounded nearest hour.  case, target statistic ratio observation time target. enables testing specific timed concentration (e.g. one hour dose C1).  sure time simulated data used, e.g., 122 dose given 120. target types, make number negative make success less target ratio, eg -122. success vector specifying success statistics, e.g. 0.4 proportion time (end-start) target, /100 max:target. example success = 0.4 success = c(0.4, 100). length must target target_type. outeq integer specifying number simulated output equation use. Default 1. free_fraction Proportion free, active drug, expressed numeric value >=0 <=1.  Default 1, .e., 100% free drug 0% protein binding. start Specify time begin PTA calculations. Default vector first observation time subjects element simdata, e.g. dose regimen. specified vector, values recycled necessary. end Specify time end PTA calculations PTA calculated start end.  Default end maximum observation time subjects element simdata, e.g. dose regimen.  specified vector, values recycled necessary. Subjects insufficient data (fewer 5 simulated observations) specified interval trigger warning. Ideally , simulated datset contain sufficient observations within interval specified start end. icen Can either "median" predictions based medians pred.type parameter value distributions, "mean".  Default "median". block block plot, new block defined dose resets (evid = 4); default 1. ... currently used

title: Create Probability of Target Attainment (PTA) object — PM_pta
code: \dontrun{ pta1 <- PM_pta$new(simEx,                  simlabels = c("600 mg daily", "1200 mg daily", "300 mg bid", "600 mg bid"),                  target = list(2^(-2:6), 1, 50),                  target_type = c("time", 144, "-max"),                  success = c(0.6, 1, 1),                  start = 120, end = 144)  pta2 <- PM_pta$new(simEx,                  target = c(2^(-2:6)),                  target_type = "time",                  success = 0.6,                  start = 120, end = 144)  pta3 <- PM_pta$new(simEx,                  simlabels = c("600 mg daily", "1200 mg daily", "300 mg bid", "600 mg bid"),                  target = list(5,10),                  target_type = c("min", "-min"),                  success = c(1,1),                  start = 120, end = 144)  pta4 <- PM_pta$new(simEx,                  simlabels = c("600 mg daily", "1200 mg daily", "300 mg bid", "600 mg bid"),                  target = makePTAtarget(mic1),                  target_type = "auc",                  success = 200,                  start = 120, end = 144)  pta5 <- PM_pta$new(simdata = simEx,                  simlabels = c("600 mg daily", "1200 mg daily", "300 mg bid", "600 mg bid"),                  target = list(makePTAtarget(mic1),5),                  target_type = c("auc","min"),                  success = c(200,1),                  start = 120, end = 144) }

code: run1 <- PM_load(1) # load the PM_result object sim1 <- run1$sim(...) # replace model and data in run1 if desired; #must be compatible with model and data in run1  mod <- PM_model$new("model.txt") # or use a model object sim2 <- mod$sim(poppar = run1, data = "newdata.csv", ...) # poppar and data necessary, model obtained from mod run1 <- PM_load(1) # load the PM_result object sim1 <- PM_sim$new(poppar = run1$final, model = newmodel, data = newdata, ...) # model and data necessary  mod <- PM_model$new("model.txt") # or use a model object sim2 <- mod$sim(poppar = run1$final, data = "newdata.csv", ...) # poppar and data necessary, model obtained from mod poppar = list(wt = 1,               mean = list(ke = 0.5, v = 100),               cov = matrix(c(0.04, 2.4, 2.8, 400), nrow = 2))  # sd not required because cov specified poppar = list(wt = c(0.1, 0.15, 0.75), # 3 distributions that sum to 1               mean = list(ke = c(2, 0.5, 1), v = c(50, 100, 200)), # 3 values for each parameter               sd = list(ke = 0.2, v = 20), # overall sd, ignoring multiple distributions               cor = matrix(c(1, 0.6, 0.7, 1), nrow = 2)) # sd required because cor specified run1 <- PM_load(1) run1$sim(..., covariate = list())` run1 <- PM_load(1) sim1 <- PM_sim$new(poppar = run1$final, covariate = list(cov = run1$cov), model = run1$model, data = "newdata.csv") corMat <- matrix(c(1, .98, .98, 1), nrow = 2) # correlation matrix for age and wt, for example covariate <- list(cov = corMat, mean = list(age = 9, wt = 32), sd = list(age = 5.5, wt = 18.8)) # note the named lists for mean and sd, and cov is treated as a correlation matrix  covMat <- matrix(c(30.25, 101.33, 101.33, 353.44), nrow = 2) covariate <- list(cov = covMat, mean = list(age = 9, wt = 32)) # equivalent covariance matrix, and sd is not required corMat <- matrix(c(1, .98, .98, 1, nrow = 2) # correlation matrix for age and wt covariate <- list(cov = corMat, mean = list(age = 9, wt = 32), sd = list(age = 5.5, wt = 18.8)) # mean and sd are required PM_sim$new(poppar = poppar , covariate = covariate) # covariates will be added to poppar for simulation regardless of the source of poppar exDat$makeNoise(list(dose = list(coeff = c(0.1, 0.1), filter = "dose > 100 & time < 200", mode = "add"), out = list(c(0.1, 0.001), mode = "exp")))

title: Object to contain results of simulation — PM_sim
code: \dontrun{ # Load results of NPAG run run1 <- PM_load(1)  # Two methods to simulate # The first uses the population prior, data, and model in run1, with "..." # as additional parameters passed to the simulator, e.g. limits, nsim, etc.  sim1 <- run1$sim(...)  # The second uses the population prior and model in run1, and a new template # data file in the working directory  sim2 <- PM_sim$new(poppar = run1, data = "newfile.csv", ...)  # These methods are entirely interchangeable. The first can accept a different # data template. The difference is that poppar must be explicitly # declared when using PM_sim$new. This makes it the method to use when poppar # is derived from the literature.  # An example of a manual prior # make 1 lognormal distribution for each parameter weights <- 1 mean <- log(c(0.7, 0.05, 100)) cov <- matrix(rep(0, length(mean)**2), ncol = length(mean)) diag(cov) <- (c(0.15, 0.15, 0.15) * mean)**2 # make the prior for the simulation poppar <- list(weights = weights, mean = mean, mat = cov)  # run simulation, assuming temp1.csv and model.txt are in working directory  sim1 <- PM_sim$new(poppar, "temp1.csv",   nsim = 15, model = "model.txt", include = 1:4, limits = NA,   noise = list(out = list(coeff = c(0.02, 0.1, 0, 0))) )  # alternatively, load the model first  mod <- PM_model$new("model.txt")  # and then simulate  sim2 <- mod$sim(poppar = poppar, data = "temp1.csv",    nsim = 15, include = 1:4, limits = NA,    noise = list(out = list(coeff = c(0.02, 0.1, 0, 0))) )  }

code: ## ------------------------------------------------ ## Method `PM_sim$new` ## ------------------------------------------------  if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Load results of NPAG run run1 <- PM_load(1)  # Two methods to simulate # The first uses the population prior, data, and model in run1, with "..." # as additional parameters passed to the simulator, e.g. limits, nsim, etc.  sim1 <- run1$sim(...)  # The second uses the population prior and model in run1, and a new template # data file in the working directory  sim2 <- PM_sim$new(poppar = run1, data = "newfile.csv", ...)  # These methods are entirely interchangeable. The first can accept a different # data template. The difference is that poppar must be explicitly # declared when using PM_sim$new. This makes it the method to use when poppar # is derived from the literature.  # An example of a manual prior # make 1 lognormal distribution for each parameter weights <- 1 mean <- log(c(0.7, 0.05, 100)) cov <- matrix(rep(0, length(mean)**2), ncol = length(mean)) diag(cov) <- (c(0.15, 0.15, 0.15) * mean)**2 # make the prior for the simulation poppar <- list(weights = weights, mean = mean, mat = cov)  # run simulation, assuming temp1.csv and model.txt are in working directory  sim1 <- PM_sim$new(poppar, "temp1.csv",   nsim = 15, model = "model.txt", include = 1:4, limits = NA,   noise = list(out = list(coeff = c(0.02, 0.1, 0, 0))) )  # alternatively, load the model first  mod <- PM_model$new("model.txt")  # and then simulate  sim2 <- mod$sim(poppar = poppar, data = "temp1.csv",    nsim = 15, include = 1:4, limits = NA,    noise = list(out = list(coeff = c(0.02, 0.1, 0, 0))) )  } # }

title: Check Pmetrics Inputs for Errors — PMcheck
text: check data errors cause analysis fail.  Note Pmetrics Version 2, function called automatically new PM_data object created, users generally longer need call function directly. PM_data$new(), data object first standardized contain required columns, since "ID", "TIME", "DOSE" "" required minimum, checked PMcheck. calling PMcheck directly, either filename Pmetrics data object memory accepted data. standardization direct calls, case format .csv matrix file fairly rigid. must following features.  Text case-sensitive. header row 1 appropriate version, currently "POPDATA DEC_11" Column headers row 2.  headers : #ID, EVID, TIME, DUR, DOSE, ADDL, II, INPUT, , CENS, OUTEQ, C0, C1, C2, C3. cell empty.  either contain value "." placeholder. Columns C3 interpreted covariates. subject records must begin TIME=0. dose events (EVID=1) must entries ID, EVID, TIME, DUR, DOSE INPUT.  ADDL II optional, ADDL 0 missing, II mandatory. observation events (EVID=0) must entries ID, EVID, TIME, , OUTEQ. observation missing, use -99; otherwise use "." placeholder cells required (e.g. INPUT observation event). covariates present data, must entry every covariate time 0 subject. covariates must numeric. times within subject ID must monotonically increasing. subject IDs must contiguous. rows must EVID TIME values. columns must numeric except ID may alpha-numeric. subjects must least one observation, missing, .e. -99. Cells needed (e.g. dose observation event, EVID=0), contain ".". use function, see example . running PMcheck looking errors errors.xlsx file, can fix errors manually directly errors.xlsx file resave .csv file. Alternatively, try fix problem(s) mdata2 <- PMcheck(mdata,fix=T).  Note now returning PMmatrix data object called mdata2 (hopefully cleaned errors) rather PMerr object returned fix=FALSE. Pmetrics handles errors following ways. columns simply order, reordered.  missing, fix must done user, .e. manually. id covariate values truncated 11 characters. Missing observations set -99 ("."). Incomplete dose records flagged user fix manually. Incomplete observation records flagged user fix manually. Subjects without EVID=1 first event flagged user fix manually. Subjects TIME != 0 first event dummy dose=0 events inserted time 0. Subjects missing covariate time 0 flagged user fix manually. Non-numeric covariates converted numeric (via factor()). Non-ordered times sorted within subject EVID=4 events; otherwise user must fix manually. Non-contiguous subject ID rows combined sorted EVID=4 events; otherwise user must fix manually. Rows missing EVID assigned value 0 DOSE  missing, 1 otherwise. Rows missing TIME value flagged user fix manually. Cells malformed NA values attempted fixed. Columns non-numeric must numeric flagged user fix manually. columns except ID. Covariate columns fixed separately (see ). Dose events censoring set uncensored, warning user.

what: Estimate renal function using various equations — add_renal
title: Estimate renal function using various equations — add_renal
text: Adds columns PM_data object creatinine clearance estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR). Creatinine clearance can estimated : Jelliffe equation paired creatinines Cockcroft-Gault equation using single creatinine. eGFR can estimated : MDRD equation CKD-EPI equation Schwartz equation children

title: Estimate renal function using various equations — add_renal
code: add_renal(   x,   method,   id = "id",   wt = "wt",   ht = "ht",   male = "male",   age = "age",   black = "black",   scr = "scr",   bun = "bun",   cysC = "cysC",   SI = F )

title: Estimate renal function using various equations — add_renal
text: x PM_data data object method character vector defining method use. Options "jelliffe" "jel" "cockcroft-gault" "cg" "mdrd" "ckd-epi" "ckd" "schwartz" fuller versions, first 4 letters required id character vector name id column x. default "id". wt character vector name weight column x.  default "wt". required "jelliffe" "cockcroft-gault" methods. Values must kilograms. ht character vector name height column x. default "ht". required "schwartz" method. Values must meters male character vector name column defining sex x. Male 1 female 0. default "male". age character vector name age column x. default "age". Values must years. black character vector name column defining black race x. Male 1 female 0. default "male". scr character vector name serum creatinine column x. Default units mg/dL, unless SI = TRUE . default name "scr". bun character vector name blood urea nitrogen column x. Default units mg/dL, unless SI = TRUE . Default name "bun". Optional Schwartz method. cysC character vector name cystatin C column x. Units always mg/L. Default "cysC". Optional Schwartz method. SI Boolean value, true, expect serum creatinine micromol/L BUN reported micromol/L urea. Default FALSE.

title: Estimate renal function using various equations — add_renal
text: column added x data object name method used calcuated values.

title: Estimate renal function using various equations — add_renal
text: Note: equations , age years, weight kilograms, height meters, cystatin C (cysC) mg/L. Serum creatinine (Scr) mg/dL blood urea nitrogen (BUN) mg/L. However, SI = TRUE, serum creatinine micromol/L BUN micromol/L urea. Missing covariate values interpolated using linear interpolation within subject. Jelliffe equation depends age, sex, weight, serum creatinine. uniquely uses two serum creatinine values separated time estimate changing renal function. \(ESS = wt * (29.3 - (0.203 * age))\) males \(ESS = wt * (25.1 - (0.175 * age))\) females \(scrAve = (Scr1 + Scr2) / 2\) \(ESS_cor = ESS * (1.035 - (0.0337 * scrAve))\) \(E = ESS_cor - 4 * wt * (Scr2 - Scr1) / (time2 - time1)\) \(CRCL = E / (14.4 * scrAve)\) ml/min/1.73m^2 Cockroft-Gault equation point estimate creatinine clearance. depends variables Jelliffe except require paired creatinines. \(CRCL = ((140 - age) * weight * K)/(72 * Scr)\) \(K\) 1 males 0.85 females MDRD equation estimates GFR. depends age, sex, black race, serum creatinine. \(eGFR = 175 * (Scr)^{-1.154} * (age)^{-0.203}\) Multiply 1.212 black. CKD-EPI equation estimates GFR. depends variables MDRD, except black longer required 2021 version used . \(eGFR = 141 * min(Scr/k, 1)^* max(Scr/k, 1)^{-1.209} * 0.993^{age}\) Multiply 1.1018 female. Schwartz equation estimates GFR children. equation used depends covariates included data. height serum creatinine: \(eGFR = 41.3 * height/scr\) (updated Scwartz equation) height, serum creatinine, cystatin C: \(eGFR = 41.6 * (height/scr)^{0.599} * (1.8/cysC)^{0.317}\) (Equation 1a) height, serum creatinine, BUN: \(eGFR = 40.7 * (height/scr)^{0.640} * (30/BUN)^{0.202}\) (Equation 1b) height, serum creatinine, cystatin C, BUN: \(eGFR = 41.1 * (height/scr)^{0.510} * (1.8/cysC)^{0.272} * (30/BUN)^{0.171}\) (Equation II) height, serum creatinine, cystatin C, BUN, male: \(eGFR = 39.1 * (height/scr)^{0.516} * (1.8/cysC)^{0.294} * (30/BUN)^{0.169} * 1.099^{male} * (height/1.4)^{1.88}\) (Equation III) Discussion strengths weaknesses equations beyond scope documentation.

title: Estimate renal function using various equations — add_renal
text: Michael Neely

title: Export plotly plot — export_plotly
text: p plot shape added. Default plotly::last_plot(). file file path suitable file extension (png, jpg, jpeg, webp, svg, pdf). Unlike save_image, file argument may include full path filename current working directory. width, height width/height exported image pixels, mutliplied scale. scale scale factor use exporting figure. Default 1.0. scale factor larger 1.0 increase image size, less 1.0 decrease image size. Note documentation save_image says argument changes resolution, true. resolution remain 72 pixels/inch (28.3 px/cm), default R. increase resolution, export .pdf .svg use external program, Adobe Acrobat, Acrobat Reader, Mac Preview. units Units width height. Default pixels ("px"). Alternatives inches ("") centimeters ("cm") show Show exported image R via base::file.show(). export format pdf, open system default pdf viewer. Default TRUE.

Many arguments save_image passed directly function.

NPAG data, support point size proportional probability point.  IT2B, elliptical distribution bivariate normal distribution centered mean plotted variable surrounding quantiles bivariate distribution plotted decreasing shades grey. Mulitvariate normal density code borrowed mvtnorm package.

FALSE suppress compartment plotting. list, can control marker characteristics, including overriding defaults. include: color Marker color (default: dodgerblue). opacity Ranging 0 (fully transparent) 1 (fully opaque). Default 0.5. size Relative size boxes, ranging 0 1.  Default 0.25. line list  additional attributes governing outline filled shapes, commonly color (default: black) width (default: 0.5). FALSE suppress lines. list, can control line characteristics, including overriding defaults. include: color Line color (default: black) width Thickness points (default: 1). Example: line = list(color = "red", width = 2) explicit data frame tibble containing two columns named add additional connecting arrows plot indicating transfer compartments. row, column contains compartment number arrow origin, column contains compartment number arrow destination. Use 0 indicate destination external sink. e.g., explicit = data.frame(= 3, = 0) implicit Similar explicit, used add dashed connecting arrows plot indicating implicit transfer compartments. row, column contains compartment number arrow origin, column contains compartment number arrow destination. Use 0 indicate destination external sink. e.g., implicit = data.frame(= 2, = 4) print TRUE, print object return . FALSE, return object. ... used.

title: Plot Pmetrics Observed vs. Predicted Objects — plot.PM_op
code: # S3 method for class 'PM_op' plot(   x,   line = list(lm = NULL, loess = NULL, ref = NULL),   marker = TRUE,   resid = FALSE,   icen = "median",   pred.type = "post",   outeq = 1,   block,   include,   exclude,   mult = 1,   legend,   log = FALSE,   grid = TRUE,   xlab,   ylab,   title,   stats = TRUE,   print = TRUE,   xlim,   ylim,   ... )

title: Plot Pmetrics Observed vs. Predicted Objects — plot.PM_op
text: x name PM_op data object loaded PM_load field PM_result, e.g. PM_result$op. line Controls characteristics lines. Unlike Pmetrics plots, plot.PM_op, line list three elements: lm  set TRUE (default) list plotly line attributes, generate linear regression form obs ~ pred. Line attributes control appearance regression line confidence interval around line. set FALSE, linear regression generated. default values elements lm list, can overriden : ci Confidence interval around regression, default 0.95. color Color regression line confidence area around line, opacity = 0.2. Default "dodgerblue". width Width regression line, default 1. dash See plotly::schema(), traces > scatter > attributes > line > dash > values. Default "solid". Example: line = list(lm = list(color = "red", dash = "longdash", width = 2)) loess set TRUE (default FALSE) list plotly line attributes, generate loess regression form obs ~ pred. list elements default values loess list lm except default style "dash". Example: line = list(lm = FALSE, loess = TRUE) ref set TRUE (default) list plotly line attributes, generate reference line slope = 1 intercept = 0. default values elements ref list : color "grey". width 1. dash "dot". Note ci argument ref list. Example: line = list(lm = FALSE, loess = TRUE, ref = list(color = "lightgrey")) line argument missing, set line = list(lm = TRUE, loess = FALSE, ref = TRUE), .e. linear regression reference line, loess regression. However, resid = T, default become line = list(lm = FALSE, loess = TRUE, ref = TRUE), .e., loess regression reference line, linear regression. marker Controls plotting symbol observations.  argument maps plotly marker object. can boolean list. TRUE plot marker default characteristics. FALSE suppress marker plotting. list, can control many marker characteristics, including overriding defaults. Use plotly plotly::schema() command console navigate traces > scatter > attributes > marker see ways marker can formatted. common : color Marker color. symbol Plotting character. See plotly::schema(), traces > scatter > attributes > marker > symbol > values. size Character size points. opacity Ranging 0 (fully transparent) 1 (fully opaque). line list  additional attributes governing outline filled shapes, commonly color width. Example: marker = list(color = "red", symbol = "triangle", opacity = 0.8, line = list(color = "black", width = 2)) Default marker = list(color = orange, shape = "circle", size = 10, opacity = 0.5, line = list(color = black, width = 1)). color BLQ points set color 90 degrees different color wheel color points using opposite_color ensure good contrast. symbol BLQ points fixed "triangle-", opacity fixed 1. Size points. resid Boolean operator generate plot weighted prediction error vs. time, plot weighted prediction error vs. prediction. Prediction error pred - obs. default loess regression indicate deviation zero prediction error. icen Can either "median" predictions based medians ofpred.type  parameter value distributions, "mean".  Default "median". pred.type Either 'post' posterior object 'pop' population object.  Default 'post'. outeq output equation plot. Default 1. block block plot, blocks defined dose reset events (EVID = 4) data. Default missing, results blocks included. include vector subject IDs include plot, e.g. c(1:3,5,15) exclude vector subject IDs exclude plot, e.g. c(4,6:14,16:20) mult Multiplication factor y axis, e.g. convert mg/L ng/mL legend Ignored plot. log Boolean operator plot y axis log base 10. argument maps   yaxis type value layout object plotly.  Use plotly plotly::schema() command console navigate layout > layoutAttributes > yaxis > type. Example: log = T grid Controls grid display. argument maps xaxis yaxis layout objects plotly.  Use plotly plotly::schema() command console navigate layout > layoutAttributes > xaxis yaxis > gridcolor gridwidth. Boolean operator. FALSE, grid plotted.  TRUE, default color grey width 1 plotted  major tick marks. list, color width can customized. Examples: grid = F grid = list(gridcolor = "black", gridwidth = 2) xlab Value x axis label. argument maps xaxis title element layout object plotly.  can simply character vector length 1 specifies name  axis, can list greater control. Use plotly plotly::schema() command console navigate layout > layoutAttributes > xaxis > title see ways customize axis label. addition plotly attributes, custom Pmetrics attribute bold  may included list element, either within font list. default bold TRUE. Examples: xlab = "Time (h)" xlab = list(text = "Time", bold = F, font = list(color = "red", family = "Arial", size = 10)) xlab = list(text = "Time", font = list(bold = T)) missing, default "Predicted" plots resid = F either "Time" "Predicted" residual plots. ylab Value y axis label. argument maps yaxis title element layout object plotly.  See xlab details. xlab specified list formatting, ylab simply character label, formatting  xlab applied ylab. format ylab independently, specify formatting list xlab. missing, default "Observed" plots resid = F either "Individual weighted residuals" "Population weighted residuals" residual plots, depending value pred.type. title Plot title. argument maps title layout object plotly.  can simply character vector length 1 specifies name  plot title, can list greater control. Use plotly plotly::schema() command console navigate layout > layoutAttributes > title see ways customize title using lists additional arguments. addition plotly attributes, custom Pmetrics attribute bold  may included list element. default bold TRUE. Examples: title = "Observed vs. Predicted" title = list(text = "Raw Data", font = list(color = "red", family = "Arial", size = 10, bold = T)) Default title. stats Add statistics linear regression plot. FALSE, suppressed. Default TRUE results default format list(x= 0.8, y = 0.1, font = list(color = "black", family = "Arial", size = 14, bold = FALSE)). coordinates relative plot lower left = (0,0), upper right = (1,1). argument maps plotly::add_text(). print TRUE, print plotly object return . FALSE, return plotly object. xlim Limits x axis vector.   argument maps   xaxis range layout object plotly.  Use plotly plotly::schema() command console navigate layout > layoutAttributes > xaxis > range. Example: xlim = c(0,1) ylim Limits y axis vector.   argument maps   yaxis range layout object plotly.  Use plotly plotly::schema() command console navigate layout > layoutAttributes > yaxis > range. Example: ylim = c(0,100) ... attributes can passed layout > xaxis/yaxis  plotly plot control formatting.  Note log, xlab, ylab, xlim, ylim  controlled layout object, provided throughout Pmetrics plotly function arguments shortcuts map layout elements.  Therefore, dots argument used specify aspects  x axis, y axis, . See plotly::schema() layout > layoutAttributes  > xaxis/yaxis options. add single axis, name list.  attributes specified without enclosing xaxis yaxis list,  applied axes. Examples: NPex$data$plot(xaxis = list(tickcolor = "black", tickfont = list(family = "Arial", size = 14, color = "black"))) #applies x axis NPex$data$plot(linecolor = "red", ticks = "inside") #applies axes .

FALSE suppress line plotting. list, functions little differently Pmetrics plotly functions. Rather controlling individual line characteristics, plot, line argument list options group based plotting, group corresponds simulated regimen. possible elements line list exactly named: color Maps plotly::plot_ly colors argument override default colors applied lines regimen. can named palette, can obtained RColorBrewer::display.brewer.() vector hexadecimal color names. title: Plot Pmetrics Simulation Objects — plot.PM_sim
text: x name PM_sim data object generated PM_sim include vector subject IDs include plot, e.g. c(1:3,5,15) . exclude vector subject IDs exclude plot, e.g. c(4,6:14,16:20) . mult Multiplication factor y axis, e.g. convert mg/L ng/mL ci Width confidence interval bands around simulated quantiles, 0 1.  0, nsim<100, plot. Default 0.95, .e. 95th percentile tails 2.5 percent excluded. binSize Width binning interval simulated concentrations, time units, e.g. hours. binSize 0.5 pull simulated concentrations +/- 0.5 hours time.  useful plotting PMsim objects made make_valid. default 0, .e. binning. obs object provided, binned similarly. outeq output equation plot. Default 1. line Controls appearance lines. can specified several ways. Default TRUE results simulated profiles summarized quantiles, default values 0.05, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 0.95. default format applied, solid black lines width 1. Numerical predictive checking calculated observations also included (see obs ). FALSE results lines plotted plot blank. NA Quantile summaries suppressed, lines joining simulated outputs plotted default format . words, profiles plotted, just quantiles. Numerical predictive checking suppressed. List quantiles formats plot following elements: probs Vector quantiles include. missing, set defaults , .e., c(0.05, 0.5, 0.95) Example: line = list(probs = c(0.25, 0.5, 0.75)). color Vector color names whose order corresponds probs. shorter probs, recycled. Default "dodgerblue", median present (prob = 0.5), line "red". Examples: line = list(color = "red") line = list(color = c("red", "blue")). fill Fill color quantile lines. Can specified several ways: FALSE (default) fill lines. TRUE fill lines default color "dodgerblue", opacity 0.2. list following elements: color Fill color name. Default "dodgerblue", e.g., fill = list(color = "red"). opacity Fill opacity. Default 0.2 e.g., fill = list(opacity = 0.3). probs Vector paired quantiles fill . Default minimum maximum quantile specified probs, fill = list(probs = c(0.05, 0.95)) specified. Including probs fill probs result error. width Vector widths pixels, color. Default 1. Example: line = list(width = 2). dash Vector dash types, color. Default "solid". See plotly::schema(), traces > scatter > attributes > line > dash > values. Example: line = list(dash = "dashdot"). marker Controls plotting symbol observations.  argument maps plotly marker object. can boolean list. TRUE plot marker default characteristics. FALSE suppress marker plotting. list, can control many marker characteristics, including overriding defaults. Use plotly plotly::schema() command console navigate traces > scatter > attributes > marker see ways marker can formatted. common : color Marker color. symbol Plotting character. See plotly::schema(), traces > scatter > attributes > marker > symbol > values. size Character size points. opacity Ranging 0 (fully transparent) 1 (fully opaque). line list  additional attributes governing outline filled shapes, commonly color width. Example: marker = list(color = "red", symbol = "triangle", opacity = 0.8, line = list(color = "black", width = 2)) Formatting applied observations included via obs argument. obs name PM_result data object PM_op field PM_result object, generated PM_load.  example, run1 <- PM_load(1) sim1 PM_sim object, sim1$plot(obs = run1) sim1$plot(obs = run1$op). specified, observations overlaid upon simulation plot enabling visual predictive check.  case, list object returned two items: $npc containing quantiles probability observations quantile (binomial test); $simsum, times observation value simulated quantile upper lower confidence intervals time. Additionally, number observations beyond 5th 95th percentiles reported binomial test P-value number different expected 10% value. quiet TRUE, suppresses message simulation report generation, defaults FALSE. legend Controls display legend. argument maps plotly layout showlegend legend arguments. either boolean operator (common) list parameters supplied plotly. See plotly::schema() > layout > layoutAttributes > legend showlegend details available options formatting.  legend supplied list,  plotly layout > layoutAttributes > showlegend value set TRUE automatically. Examples: legend = T legend = list(orientation = "h", font = list(color = "blue")) Default FALSE log Boolean operator plot y axis log base 10. argument maps   yaxis type value layout object plotly. title: Summary Statistics for Final Cycle — summary.PM_final
text: output data frame. NPAG 4 columns: value value summary statistic par name parameter type Either WtMed weighted median, MAWD MAWD (see details) percentile Requested lower, 0.5 (median), upper quantiles IT2B 6 columns: mean Parameter mean value se.mean Standard error mean cv.mean Error mean divided mean var Variance parameter values se.var Standard error variance summary Name summary statistic

title: Summary Statistics for Final Cycle — summary.PM_final
text: #' function usually called $summary() method PM_final objects within PM_result. function can called directly PM_final object. NPAG runs, function generate weighted medians central tendencies population points 95% confidence interval (95% CI) around median, median absolute weighted deviation (MAWD) median measure variance, 95% CI.  estimates correspond weighted mean, 95% CI mean, variance, 95% CI variance, respectively, sample normal distribution. estimate non-parametric summaries, function uses Monte Carlo simulation approach, creating  1000 x npoint samples replacement weighted marginal distribution parameter, npoint number support points model.  example, 100 support points, npoint = 100, Ka, 1000 sets 100 samples drawn weighted marginal distribution values Ka.  1,000 sets npoint values, median MAWD calculated, MAWD equal median absolute difference point median set.  output npoint estimates weighted median npoint estimates MAWD parameter, median, 2.5th, 97.5th percentiles can found point estimates 95% confidence interval limits, respectively, weighted median MAWD. IT2B runs, function return mean variance parameter, standard errors terms, using $$SE_mean = SD/\sqrt(nsub)$$ $$SE_var = var * \sqrt(2/(nsub-1))$$.
